name: body
description_1: Collection of matter with a defined contiguous border in three-dimensional space.
description_2: A group of matter that occupies a specific| continuous region within three-dimensional space.

name: mass
description_1: Quantity that determines an object’s inertia and its response to a force.
description_2: A fundamental characteristic of an object| once thought to be tied to the amount of matter present| but later found to differ even among particles with seemingly similar amounts of matter.

name: time
description_1: Continued sequence of events that occurs in an apparently irreversible succession from the past| through the present| and into the future.
description_2: The ongoing progression of events from the past to the present| and into the future| often considered an irreversible process.

name: vacuum
description_1: Space devoid of matter.
description_2: An area completely empty of any physical matter.

name: speed
description_1: The magnitude of the change of position over time.
description_2: The rate at which an object's location shifts over a given period.

name: velocity
description_1: The speed in combination with the direction of motion of an object.
description_2: The combined measurement of how fast something is moving and in what direction.

name: acceleration
description_1: The rate of change of the velocity of an object with respect to time.
description_2: The measure of how quickly an object's speed changes over time.

name: impulse
description_1: Change in momentum of an object.
description_2: The variation in an object's momentum due to external influences.

name: momentum
description_1: Product of the mass and velocity of an object.
description_2: A measure obtained by multiplying an object's mass by its speed.

name: displacement
description_1: Change is position of an object.
description_2: The shift in an object's location from one point to another.

name: distance
description_1: Measurement of how far apart the objects are.
description_2: A measurement indicating how much space separates two objects.

name: force
description_1: Influence that can cause an object to change its velocity unless counterbalanced by other forces.
description_2: A push or pull that can alter an object's speed or direction unless other factors counter it.

name: gravity
description_1: Fundamental interaction observed as mutual attraction between all things that have mass.
description_2: A fundamental force that causes any two objects with mass to attract each other.

name: newton
description_1: The unit of force in the international system of units (SI). One newton is| the force needed to accelerate one kilogram of mass at the rate of one metre per second squared in the direction of the applied force.
description_2: A standard unit for measuring force| defined as the amount of force required to move a kilogram of mass by one meter per second squared.

name: first law of motion
description_1: Physics law that states that a body remains at rest| or in motion at a constant speed in a straight line| except insofar as it is acted upon by a force.
description_2: Physics law that states that an object will stay still or continue moving in a straight line at the same speed unless influenced by an external force.

name: inertia
description_1: Tendency of object in motion to stay in motion and objects at rest to stay at rest.
description_2: The natural tendency of objects to maintain their current state| either moving or at rest| unless acted upon by an external force.

name: second law of motion
description_1: At any instant of time| the net force on a body is equal to the body's acceleration multiplied by its mass or| equivalently| the rate at which the body's momentum is changing with time.
description_2: At any given moment| the total force on an object is equal to the object's mass multiplied by its acceleration| or the rate at which its momentum changes over time.

name: third law of motion
description_1: If two bodies exert forces on each other| these forces have the same magnitude but opposite direction.
description_2: When two objects apply forces on each other| these forces are equal in strength but act in opposite directions.

name: newtons law of gravitation
description_1: Every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force that is proportional to the product of their masses| and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers.
description_2: Every object in the universe pulls on every other object| with the force being stronger if the objects have more mass and weaker as the distance between them increases.

name: weight
description_1: Force acting on an object due to acceleration of gravity.
description_2: The pull experienced by an object due to the gravitational acceleration of a planet or celestial body.

name: free fall
description_1: Any motion of a body where gravity is the only force acting upon it.
description_2: A type of movement where an object is only influenced by gravitational pull.

name: space
description_1: Three-dimensional continuum containing positions and directions.
description_2: A boundless| three-dimensional field that includes all possible positions and directions.

name: projectile
description_1: Object propelled by the application of an external force and then moves freely under influence of gravity and air resistance.
description_2: An object thrown or launched into the air| subject only to gravity and air resistance.

name: centripetal force
description_1: Force that makes a body follow a curved path. The direction of this force is orthogonal to the motion of the body and towards the fixed point of the instantaneous center of curvature of the path.
description_2: The inward force required to keep an object moving in a circular path.

name: kepler's first law
description_1: The orbit of a planet is an ellipse with the Sun at one of the two foci.
description_2: Planets move in elliptical orbits with the Sun at one foci.

name: kepler's second law
description_1: A line segment joining a planet and the Sun sweeps out equal areas during equal intervals of time.
description_2: A planet sweeps out equal areas in equal times as it orbits the Sun| meaning it moves faster when closer to the Sun and slower when farther away.

name: kepler's third law
description_1: The ratio of the square of an object's orbital period with the cube of the semi-major axis of its orbit is the same for all objects orbiting the same primary.
description_2: For objects orbiting the same star| if you take the square of the time it takes them to complete an orbit| and compare it to the cube of their orbits semi-major axis| that ratio will be the same.

name: orbit
description_1: Curved trajectory of an object such as the trajectory of a planet around a star| or a natural satellite around a planet etc. Normally| refers to a regularly repeating trajectory| although it may also refer to a non-repeating trajectory.
description_2: The curved path of an object| such as a planet or satellite| around another object due to gravity.

name: orbital period
description_1: Amount of time a given astronomical object takes to complete one orbit around another object.
description_2: The time it takes for an object to complete one orbit around another object.

name: ellipse
description_1: A plane curve surrounding two focal points| such that the sum of the distances to the focal points is a constant.
description_2: An oval-shaped curve| the path of planets in their orbits according to Kepler’s laws.

name: foci
description_1: A point that helps define an ellipse| parabola or hyperbola.
description_2: Two fixed points inside an ellipse; in planetary orbits| one focus is typically occupied by the Sun.

name: energy
description_1: Quantitative property that is transferred to a body or to a physical system| recognizable in the performance of work and in the form of heat and light.
description_2: The capacity to do work or cause change; exists in various forms like kinetic| potential| thermal| etc.

name: potential energy
description_1: Energy held by an object due to its position relative to other objects| stresses within itself| elastic charge or other factors.
description_2: The energy an object possesses due to its position or configuration.

name: kinetic energy
description_1: Energy held by an object due to its motion.
description_2: The energy an object has due to its motion.

name: law of conservation of energy
description_1: Total energy in an isolated system remains constant.
description_2: Energy cannot be created or destroyed| only transferred or transformed from one form to another.

name: joule
description_1: Unit of energy equal to the amount of work done when a force of one newton displaces a mass through a distance of one meter in direction of that force.
description_2: The unit of energy in the International System of Units (SI)| equivalent to the energy transferred when applying a force of one newton over a distance of one meter.

name: work
description_1: Energy transfer to or from an object via application of force along displacement.
description_2: The transfer of energy when a force is applied to an object causing it to move; calculated as force times distance.

name: heat
description_1: Thermal energy transferred between systems due to a temperature difference.
description_2: A form of energy transfer between objects due to a temperature difference.

name: temperature
description_1: Physical quantity that quantitatively expresses the attribute of hotness or coldness. Measured with a thermometer| and represents the average kinetic energy of the vibrating and colliding atoms making up a substance.
description_2: A physical quantity that measures the degree of hotness or coldness of a substance. It is measured using a thermometer and represents the average kinetic energy of the atoms vibrating and colliding within the substance.

name: kelvin
description_1: Base unit of temperature. Represented on an absolute temperature scale that starts at the absolute zero.
description_2: The fundamental unit of temperature| measured on an absolute scale that begins at absolute zero.

name: absolute zero
description_1: The lowest temperature that is theoretically possible| at which the motion of particles which constitutes heat would be minimal.
description_2: Value of temperature equal to -273.15°C or zero the Kelvin scale.

name: power
description_1: Amount of energy transferred or converted per unit time
description_2: Rate at which energy is transferred or transformed over a specific time interval.

name: watt
description_1: Unit of power| equal to 1 joule per second. Used to quantify the rate of energy transfer.
description_2: The unit of power in the SI system| representing one joule of energy transferred per second.

name: electric potential
description_1: Amount of work or energy required per unit of electric charge to move the charge from a reference point to a specific point in an electric field.
description_2: The amount of energy or work needed per unit of electric charge to move the charge from a reference point to a specific location within an electric field.
alt names: electric field potential| potential drop| electrostatic potential

name: volt
description_1: Unit of electric potential| electric potential difference (voltage)| and electromotive force in the international system of units.
description_2: Electric potential between two points of a conductive wire when an electric current of one ampere dissipates one watt of power between those points.

name: amper
description_1: Unit of electric current in the international system of units. Equal to 1 coulomb moving past a point per second.
description_2: The standard unit for measuring electric current in the international system of units| equivalent to the movement of 1 coulomb of charge past a point per second.

name: coulomb
description_1: Unit of electric charge| equal to the electric charge delivered by 1 ampere current in 1 second and is defined in terms of elementary charge (e)| at about 6.24e18 e.
description_2: A unit of electric charge| defined as the charge carried by a current of 1 ampere flowing for 1 second| and approximately equal to 6.24 x 10^18 elementary charges (e).

name: voltage
description_1: Difference in electric potential between two points. In static electric field| corresponds to the work needed per unit of charge to move a positive test charge from the first point to the second point.
description_2: The difference in electric potential between two points| corresponding to the work required per unit charge to move a positive test charge between those points in a static electric field.
alt names: electrical potential difference| electric pressure| electric tension

name: electric current
description_1: Flow of charged particles| such as electrons or ions| moving through an electrical conductor or space.
description_2: Net rate of flow of electric charge throguh a surface.

name: electrical insulator
description_1: Thermal energy transfered between systems due to a temperature difference.
description_2: A material that resists the free flow of electric current.

name: electrical conductor
description_1: Object or type of material that allows the flow of charge in one or more directions.
description_2: An object or material that allows the movement of electric charge in one or more directions.
